verses.text: A wise son listens to his father's disciplined instruction, but a scoffer does not hear rebuke.
verses.comment: The Hebrew word for 'instruction' implies both teaching and correction, echoing the importance of family and spiritual guidance. Throughout Scripture, listening to parental authority is aligned with honoring God’s order (see Prov 1:8).

verses.text: From the fruit of one's mouth a person will eat good, but the soul of the treacherous craves violence.
verses.comment: Positive words are rewarded, emphasizing the spiritual effect of speech. This foreshadows the teaching of Jesus on our words in Matthew 12:36.

verses.text: Whoever guards his mouth preserves his life; he who opens wide his lips comes to ruin.
verses.comment: Self-control and moderation in speech are crucial for spiritual maturity. The apostle James echoes this in his epistle (see James 3:6).

verses.text: The sluggard craves but gets nothing, but the soul of the diligent is richly supplied.
verses.comment: The contrast between laziness and diligence underscores virtue through effort and cooperation with grace, a central theme for spiritual growth throughout the Bible.

verses.text: A righteous man hates falsehood, but the wicked bring shame and disgrace.
verses.comment: Hating lies aligns with God's character as Truth (see Psalm 119:163 and John 14:6).

verses.text: Righteousness guards him whose way is blameless, but sin overtakes the wicked.
verses.comment: Those who walk in righteousness find spiritual protection. Righteousness is not only moral but covenantal: related to being joined to God's people.

verses.text: One pretends to be rich but has nothing, another pretends to be poor but has great wealth.
verses.comment: Appearances can be deceiving. This lesson warns against putting faith in material status instead of spiritual riches. Jesus’ parable of the rich fool echoes this (Luke 12:21).

verses.text: A person's wealth is the ransom for his life, but the poor do not even hear threats.
verses.comment: Material wealth can offer protection, but spiritual poverty is safer from earthly dangers. True richness comes from spiritual security.

verses.text: The light of the righteous shines bright, but the lamp of the wicked will be put out.
verses.comment: Light is used in both literal and spiritual senses throughout scripture. Jesus calls His followers to be 'light of the world' (Matt. 5:16).

verses.text: By pride comes nothing but strife, but wisdom is with those who seek counsel.
verses.comment: Community and listening to advice elevate wisdom, reflecting the spiritual principle of humility and learning from tradition and elders.

verses.text: Wealth gained by fraud dwindles, but whoever gathers by hand increases it.
verses.comment: 'Little by little' ethic mirrors the value of gradual spiritual growth, as both wealth and holiness are built patiently over time.

verses.text: Hope deferred makes the heart sick, but a desire fulfilled is a tree of life.
verses.comment: The 'tree of life' motif recurs from Genesis, alluding to spiritual satisfaction found ultimately in union with God.

verses.text: Whoever despises the word will be destroyed, but whoever fears the commandment will be rewarded.
verses.comment: Respect for God's word leads to blessing, reflecting the necessity of obedience to divine instruction, as emphasized throughout Scripture.

verses.text: The teaching of the wise is a fountain of life, turning one away from the snares of death.
verses.comment: Spiritual wisdom is life-giving, reminiscent of Christ’s teaching on 'living water' in John 4:14.

verses.text: Good understanding wins favor, but the way of the treacherous is hard.
verses.comment: True wisdom brings grace and favor. The burdens of sin are a recurring theme throughout scripture and point to the need for divine mercy.

verses.text: Every prudent man acts with knowledge, but a fool flaunts his folly.
verses.comment: Wisdom acting through prudence is praised in tradition. Foolishness is exposed, reinforcing the biblical value of discernment.

verses.text: An evil messenger falls into trouble, but a faithful envoy brings healing.
verses.comment: The healing imagery here can be viewed messianically, as Jesus is the ultimate faithful envoy who brings spiritual healing (Isa. 53:5).

verses.text: Poverty and shame will come to him who ignores correction, but whoever listens to instruction will be honored.
verses.comment: Correction is seen as a grace that lifts up an individual, echoing the wisdom tradition’s call to humility.

verses.text: A desire fulfilled is sweet to the soul, but to turn away from evil is detestable to fools.
verses.comment: Spiritual fulfillment brings deep satisfaction. To hate turning from evil shows a deeper spiritual blindness needing healing and conversion.

verses.text: Whoever walks with the wise becomes wise, but the companion of fools will suffer harm.
verses.comment: Association shapes character. This truth is affirmed by Paul in the New Testament (1 Cor. 15:33). Community is vital for growing in wisdom.

verses.text: Disaster pursues sinners, but the righteous are rewarded with good.
verses.comment: Ultimate justice is seen here: sin attracts consequence, but righteousness leads to spiritual blessings.

verses.text: A good man leaves an inheritance to his children's children, but a sinner's wealth is laid up for the righteous.
verses.comment: Long-term vision and legacy are emphasized as virtues. Spiritual inheritance parallels this, with the treasury of grace handed down through generations.

verses.text: The fallow ground of the poor yields much food, but injustice sweeps it away.
verses.comment: Distributive justice is commended. God provides for the lowly, but human corruption disrupts that divine order.

verses.text: Whoever spares the rod hates his son, but he who loves him disciplines him diligently.
verses.comment: Correction is an act of love, not harshness. The New Testament applies this principle to God’s discipline of His children (Heb. 12:6).

verses.text: The righteous eats to satisfy his soul, but the belly of the wicked will go hungry.
verses.comment: God nourishes those who belong to Him, both physically and spiritually. Psalm 34:10 expands this promise to the faithful who seek the Lord.
